column116:
Market research - planning to launch a local-curriculum provision in Tashkent, specifically designed to serve the needs of the local community. This initiative aims to provide high-quality education that is culturally relevant and aligned with national standards while benefiting from the school’s established expertise, facilities, and teaching practices. The new provision will complement existing offerings and broaden access to quality education for families in the area.; Offering more subject options (3) in IGCSE/AS/A2. We have done a student survey and will be looking at adding Media Studies, Politics and Global Perspectives. We will also group more groups in Business, Travel and Tourism, Seperate Sciences and History to allow more students to choose these.; As part of market research, we need to understand how many families within our target demographic—those who can afford our school fees—have children with special educational needs (SEN). This information will help determine whether it is viable to offer a tailored fee structure for these students, as they typically require 1:1 support. A key consideration will be staffing, as the school currently has only one qualified SEN teacher, which may limit the number of students we can support and influence any decisions about additional resourcing or adjustments to the staffing model.; Marketing will play a key role in supporting student recruitment and retention, with a particular focus on promoting the strengths of the new school, including its facilities, staffing, and overall learning environment. The MAC team will make strategic use of existing data to analyse competitor provision and identify areas where the school can offer a clearly differentiated and superior experience. This will enable the school to position its offer confidently within the local market and communicate its unique strengths more effectively to prospective families.

A central focus of the marketing strategy will remain the school’s British School Overseas (BSO) status, as the only BSO-accredited school in the country. This distinction provides a significant competitive advantage and will be used consistently as a key message across all marketing platforms. The forthcoming BSO inspection report, in which the school was judged to be outstanding against almost all standards, will further strengthen this narrative and provide strong external validation of the quality of education, leadership, and pastoral care on offer.

By aligning market analysis with a clear articulation of the school’s unique strengths, the marketing strategy will support sustained growth, enhance the school’s reputation, and reinforce its position as the leading choice for British international education in the region.

The Senior High School Entrance Examination Class is positioned as the school’s “Domestic Academic Flagship Program.” Together with the International Department, it forms a “Dual‑Track, Transfer‑Ready Pathway Matrix”:
•International Track: MYP → IGCSE → A level → Overseas University
•Domestic Examination Track: National Curriculum → Local Senior High School Entrance Examination → Top Local High Schools or Post exam transition to the International Curriculum for overseas university preparation
The two tracks complement each other, strengthening the school’s brand stability and risk resilience while providing students with greater flexibility.
2. Curriculum System: National Standards + School Based Enhancement
•Core: Full implementation of the National Curriculum Standards, aligned closely with examination requirements.
•School Based Enhancement: Chinese (classical poetry, writing), Mathematics (competition style logic & exam focused drills), English (grammar, reading, listening & speaking), Science (experimental operations), Study Skills, and Physical Training.
•Schedule: 39 periods per week, including morning reading and evening supervised study, synchronized with the International Department timetable.
3. Teaching Structure: Dedicated Team + Independent Teaching Research
•Staffing: Dedicated teachers for Chinese, Mathematics, English, and Moral Education (the latter also teaching in the International Department). Other subjects are supported by existing faculty.
•Management: A National Curriculum Coordinator oversees curriculum delivery, teacher management, and parent communication. Subject based teaching research remains independent to ensure focus and consistency, with cross department exchange encouraged once the program is established.
4. Initial Setup
•Class Size: ≤25 students per class.
•Fees & Services: Tuition, school bus, uniform, and meals are aligned with the International Department.
•Support: Tailored ECA options and dedicated office space for teachers’ preparation and collaboration.; 1. Domestic Division: Anchored in the national curriculum, with a strong focus on Chinese language, mathematical thinking, and scientific inquiry. Demonstrates strong performance in academic results and habit formation. Students may progress to Zhongkao/Gaokao pathways or transfer into international programmes.
International Division: Maintains the features of IB PYP and integrated curricula, emphasizing inquiry-based learning, interdisciplinarity, English proficiency, and a wide range of co-curricular opportunities.
3. Core Structure: Small-Class Format & Shared Resources
•Class size capped at 26 students; tuition set at approximately 68% of that of the international class.
•Schedule: 35 core lessons + 4 sessions for morning reading/homework support, aligned with the international division’s timetable.
•Shared resources include transportation, uniforms, meals, ECAs, and school-based specialty programmes (Sports, Arts, STEAM).
•Facilities: Classrooms L301 and L302.
4. Management Model: Independent Academic Division + Unified Functional Support
•A Director for the Domestic Curriculum Division will be appointed to oversee teaching and daily operations.
